Both companies, Packers and Hearthside, have gone through a series of private equity acquisitions over the past two decades. Our report traced how government workers‚Äô retirement dollars have helped fund many of those acquisitions along the way.

This is how public pension officials have chosen to deploy retirees‚Äô savings ‚Äî investing in private equity funds that are motivated to seek profits anywhere possible, no matter the social consequences ‚Äî and that includes buying companies premised on outsourcing factory labor.

Investors in private equity funds can‚Äôt tell the future, and don‚Äôt know exactly how private equity funds will use their money. But public pension officials in Pennsylvania knew from the start that Packers‚Äô first private equity buyer was eager to target the ‚Äúindustrial outsourcing‚Äù sector. They invested $100 million worth of workers‚Äô savings in the fund, anyway.
Outsourcing invariably means paying workers lower wages; outsourcing factory work inevitably means underpaying workers to perform hazardous jobs.
It should come as no surprise that Packers has reportedly relied

on undocumented workers to clean meatpacking plants, since the overnight sanitation workers get paid substantially less than workers on day shifts. Perhaps it should be equally unsurprising both Packers and Hearthside were eventually accused of illegally employing migrant children.

We already knew public employees were helping fund the Billionaire Factory. Now, we‚Äôve learned who cleans it: the most vulnerable workers in America, including children, who are risking life and limb to make some of the wealthiest people in the world even richer.
